title: Basic Accounting
headline: Explore the principles of accounting and learn how to use unique visualization tools in this free online course.
description: This course provides the building blocks of accounting and employs innovative business simulations to explain concepts like revenue, costs, assets and liabilities. We show you how the ‘accrual’ principle creates a fundamental difference between profit and cash flow and how double-entry bookkeeping ensures that the ledger is always balanced. This course covers financial statements, accounting terminology and more.
courseDescription:
This course is accredited by the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants (CIMA). We believe that the best way to learn is through genuine understanding and experience, which is why we present a set of ground-breaking visualization models that explain accounting transactions and balances using the analogy of water pipes and tanks. These help you to develop an intuitive understanding of how accounting works as a simple, connected system.

The models used in this course are used by leading universities to help their students understand financial concepts. This course assumes no prior knowledge and gradually introduces all the building blocks of accounting such as revenue, costs, assets, liabilities and equity through a series of ground-breaking business simulations and case studies.

We show you how the ‘accrual’ principle creates a fundamental difference between profit and cashflow and how double-entry bookkeeping keeps ledgers balanced. Such lessons help you to get comfortable with financial statements and terminology. Whether you are completely new to finance or simply want an engaging refresher, this course provides an intuitive understanding of accounting. Sign up to take control of your personal or business finances.

  • Revenue

  • In the example of selling oranges, the business would record revenue when the sale of oranges occurred. A good way to think about revenue is money "earned" by the business from the sale of products or services. Or more accurately, revenue is the best estimate of the amount of money generated from the sale of products or the provision of services.

    Due to the accrual principle, revenue is not the same as cash receipts. Cash receipts are the amounts of money actually paid to the business, whereas revenue is an abstract estimate. We will look at exactly how revenue and cash receipts are connected by the creation of a receivables balance in the next topic.

    Unfortunately accountants always use many different terms for the same thing. Revenue can be called "turnover" or also just "sales". They all mean exactly the same thing. We will use the terms interchangeably through the course so that you get comfortable with each of them.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The Accrual Principle states that: "Accountants should record transactions in the periods to which they relate, rather than just when the cashflows from the transactions occur."
    • In accrual accounting both non-monetary transactions, such as revenue, and monetary transactions, like cash receipts, need to be recorded
    • Disadvantages: accrual accounting is more complex then cash accounting due to the need for estimation and judgement, and it is no longer about simple measurement
    • Advantages: accrual accounting offers a fuller picture of the state of a business’ finances at any given time. This means that its accounts can more accurately reflect its operating reality than if it were simply recording cash transactions
    • In practice, all companies of significant size are required by law to use accrual accounting
